In many ways Shadow of the Tomb Raider is an improvement over Rise, but it also feels as if it took several steps backwards. Of all the times Lara has been to Peru (which is surprisingly often), this is the most we've ever got to engage with local cultures, even if the story mainly concerns a displaced Maya civilisation. On the other hand the amount of hub areas with side quests slow down the game massively for what amounts to fetch quests that feel more at home in Deus Ex than it does Tomb Raider. I also don't think the developers realised Lara interacting with active civilisations means she's just stealing artefacts from people's houses. The platforming gameplay is strict to the point of feeling buggy at times. It all works but mistime a jump even slightly and it's over for Lara, which also takes the wind out of several cinematic scenes since on a first try you'll likely be going through it over and over again attempting to get that one jump right (particularly frustrating in Deadly Obsession where you can only save between campfires, easily wasting about 20 minutes at a time). Carrying over from previous Survivor titles, there is also something so horrifying in that every archaeological site Lara visits ends up being utterly destroyed by her merely passing through.

All in all it is still a very good game, but one with a bit of an identity crisis (mainly in the gameplay department, whereas Tomb Raider 2013 felt more embarrassed about being Tomb Raider). Second best in the trilogy, below Rise.

Later, I played "Rise of the Tomb Raider" on the Xbox 360 and instantly fell in love with the series. The atmosphere, characters, and story all came together to create my ultimate comfort game.

I want to say the same about Shadow of the Tomb Raider, but I simply can‚Äôt. There are parts I genuinely enjoyed‚Äîlike the fast-paced, chaotic prologue, and the stunning presentation of the "D√≠a de Muertos" festival with its vibrant colors and incredible ambience. However, the puzzles are where the game lost me. They aren‚Äôt difficult to solve, but they tend to drag on and test your patience more than your logic. Feeling a mixed bag of emotions as I am writing this review but at the very least I can safely say that this game is definitely worth a shot. 

The high points are really really high but the low points are equally abysmal so the overall experience is somewhat rocky (and janky).

Platforming will be one of your biggest gripes as you progress through locations, slowly morphing from being extremely fluid and sticky to simply unresponsive by the later quests and missions in the game. 

Some side quests drag along for an unnecessarily long amount of time (this critique is specifically for the main quests, the dlc quests are much more intriguing and well paced).

You will spend a lot less time in combat sections in comparison to the previous iterations. A lot more time will be spent exploring and also actively "tomb raiding", making Lara live up to the name of the title for once. 

Paititi (which acts as the main hub for a large segment of the game) will feel like a grinding halt in progress. Over time however it will a.) grow on you or b.) something you completely despise. There is also the lucrative option c.) which is that the game will force you to return to this segment regardless, so its best that you learn to love it with all of its flaws.

Stealth in combat is done incredibly well. There are multiple ways to take down enemies from the dark, hide their bodies, attack sneakily from canopies and a plethora of other fun options. There are also unique trap arrows and ammunition options to choose from. The biggest shame however is the fact that the game makes you resort to using your bow for a combat for a majority of the Paititi section, along with restricting your clothing to "traditional" tribal attire (which is pretty annoying).

Overall, out of the three games in the survivor trilogy, this is one that I find myself returning to constantly. There has been a clear focus on explorability and environments. In my opinion, the story (so far, I'm yet to finish the final few missions) is much stronger for me in comparison to the previous titles. There might be issues with pacing and some amount of jank, but the game makes up for it with its pretty much constant action and endless amounts of in game content. If possible, I definitely recommend getting the dlc's as the tombs present within the same are absolutely excellent.

This game is awesome!

I've been a fan of Tomb Raider ever since 1998, when I bought Tomb Raider Platinum for PS1.
I immedietly loved the reboot of Survivor and thoroughly enjoyed Rise, even though it had small pacing problems.

Now, with Shadow I haven't been expecting anything more than Rise. Rise 2.0 That was my expectation. Boy was I wrong!
The pacing issues are gone. Every little step feels engaging. The music is superb and atmospheric. The constant surprises and little shock moments were always keeping me sharp and on my toes. It feels very intense to play this game. Especially blind, i.e. without any help from game guides.

The crafting is streamlined to a resonable level. It doesn't get in the way like in Rise. Although as a little gun nerd, I have some criticism about realism. But it doesn't get in the way.
The climbing is exhilirating and especially without the little cues it feels very important.
Exploration and the puzzles are magnificent. I had some real head scratchers and that is how I like it. That is litterally the core of the Tomb Raider experience.
Combat is well done. Not too flashy and not too realistic. It is a good balance. And one can almost always choose to go sneaky instead of noisy. That also adds to the intensity.
It is a end of the world king of story, but that is okay. She can save the world, too.

All in all this game isn't just something for fans of the franchise, but also for players that seek a challenge and want to be entertained.

Have fun everyone!
